awd_titl_txt: Is Better Access to Information Effective in Improving Labor Market Outcomes? Experimental Evidence
awd_abstract_narration:
Provision of social insurance for low income people is not efficient for a variety of reasons, including lack of information.  Similarly, labor markets in these areas do not function efficiently, especially for young women, to create pathways for employment to get them out poverty and improve their wellbeing.  The proposed research will use field experiments to study the effects of information on improving efficiency of the provision of social insurance and employment for low income people, especially of young women.  The project consists of two studies.  The first study investigates how improved information flows through the bureaucracy improves the delivery of social benefits to impoverished recipients.  It will also study the mechanisms through which information affects bureaucratic behavior and willingness to adopt information enhanced management tools. The second project will study how information flows influences the efficiency of labor markets in low income areas. The results of this research project will provide important policy inputs for poverty reduction and will help establish the US as a global leader in poverty reduction programs.

This study will use two randomized control trial methods to study the effects of improved information on the provision of social insurance and employment among low income people.  The first study aims to understand how improving the flow of information within a multi-tiered bureaucratic hierarchy can improve implementation of social protection programs. It examines these issues in the context of timely delivery of wages to impoverished workfare participants.  The experimental evaluation considers whether providing improved information at multiple levels of the bureaucracy is complimentary, the mechanisms through which information influences administrator behavior, and willingness to adopt information enhancing management tools. The second study examines information flows in the context of a government-funded training and job placement program. It specifically asks whether community members can more effectively recruit high-potential candidates for training and improve long-term employment and social outcomes for poor youth. The research will also examine how information that youth receive affects program participation and job retention by gender. Insights from this study will inform understanding of how information by local recruiters affects match quality and labor force composition, individual employment outcomes, and youths' economic and social wellbeing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As rural economies transition out of agriculture, job seekers can sometimes find adjustments difficult: Young job entrants have relatively high education and seek higher-paying wage jobs, but may not find jobs that suit their education and aspirations in rural areas. For those with more limited education, the decline in agricultural employment opportunities leaves them without access to low-skilled jobs that were relatively more abundant in the past, making them particularly vulnerable during economic contractions or seasonal fluctuations. Publicly-managed active labor market programs aim to smooth economic transitions so that workers at both ends of the spectrum can adapt to the changing economy and cope with shocks, but they have varied impacts, suggesting design features are crucial to their effectiveness.  We study two major public sector efforts to support both types of workers in India, where rural employment has declined from 60 percent in 2000 to 44 percent by 20171. Our focus in both studies is on the structure of local bureaucracies and the ways in which information flows relate to program outcomes.

The first study focuses on the Indian government’s workfare guarantee program, known as MGNREGA, which provides local job opportunities to low-income, low-skilled workers and serves as a safety net to support them. We examine how the cost of acquiring management-relevant program information affects bureaucratic officers' ability to deliver program benefits – namely, workfare payments - to rural workers. By randomizing the level at which we provide information in the hierarchy, our experimental study specifically examines whether there are complementarities to providing similar information at multiple levels of the bureaucracy. We find that reducing costs of information through providing access to an e-management tool, co-developed with the government, reduced the time workers needed to wait to receive their electronically-deposited wages by 11 percent, compared to control areas pre-intervention. Information cost reductions at both higher and lower levels of the bureaucracy improve implementation similarly; we find the cost reductions are substitutes. Crucially for the population the program intends to support, the low-cost tool did not simply reduce time to payment, it also increased days worked by rural laborers by 19 percent –  further supporting their overall well-being. Alongside these improvements, when senior officials received this information tool, we find evidence of improved staff management, as they reduced the use of frequent staff transfers.

The second study examines public sector efforts to train and place young adults from poor, rural families in wage work, often in cities. While this program particularly aims to support young women, who face bigger barriers to joining training and jobs, outcomes generally favor men. The research again focuses on the ways in which bureaucrats are involved in active labor market programs – this time in a  vocational training program and at the point of program entrance (recruitment to enroll). Here we compare training enrollment and job placements for young men and women based on whether recruitment was completed by relatively more senior bureaucrats, who centralized access to information about training and jobs through local recruitment fairs, or by local frontline bureaucrats – typically women affiliated with rural development programs, who would have better knowledge of which youth would be interested in the program. In this case, quasi-experimental analysis suggest that leveraging the more senior officials’ ability to centralize information about labor markets was crucial to recruiting young women, whose training enrollments and job placements doubled when handled by higher-level administrators, reducing gender gaps in outcomes by 44 percent. To the contrary, there were no improvements in training enrollment or job outcomes in areas where local female bureaucrats recruited youth to training. This final result holds in both quasi-experimental analysis and in a large-scale randomized control trial in a state in eastern India, and runs contrary to the commonly-promoted approach of having female frontline workers serve as last-mile agents of government outreach for social protection programs.

Both studies advance our understanding of how the design of public sector programs can support the most vulnerable: In the first case, providing easy access to timely inputs to inform officials’ daily tasks had important consequences in terms of improving implementation of a major active labor market program, particularly for overburdened officials. Officers shared information through the hierarchy, leading workfare results to be similarly positive regardless of where in the hierarchy information was provided. In the second case, the level at which implementation occurs mattered given the role of more senior bureaucrats in centralizing information access for constituents with poorer access to information about training and jobs in the first place. Results suggest effective program designs depend on the nature of information asymmetries and bureaucrats’ ability to leverage the information provided.

 

1 World Development Indicators for percentage of total employment in agriculture in India for 2000 and 2017 using the modeled ILO estimates. Data available here; accessed November 8, 2023.
